intro: Boehmeria massuriensis, commonly known as the Japanese nettle, is a herbaceous plant native to East Asia. It belongs to the family Urticaceae, which includes many species of stinging plants. The plant is characterized by its soft, hairy leaves and clusters of small, greenish-white flowers. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forests and stream banks. Its fibrous stems have been historically used for making paper and textiles.
